title: The Psychology of Listicles

multiple-choice.question: Why are listicles so popular?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a new format that has only been around for a few years.

options.label: B
options.text: They are easy to read and digest, making them a convenient way to process information.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a way to showcase creativity and imagination.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a way to promote products and services.

multiple-choice.question: What is cognitive fluency, and how does it relate to listicles?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive fluency is a measure of how difficult it is to think about something, and listicles make it harder to think.

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive fluency is a measure of how easy it is to think about something, and listicles make it easier to think.

options.label: C
options.text: Cognitive fluency is a measure of how much information is presented, and listicles present too much information.

options.label: D
options.text: Cognitive fluency is a measure of how much time it takes to read something, and listicles take too much time to read.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between listicles and other forms of information?

options.label: A
options.text: Listicles are more formal and serious than other forms of information.

options.label: B
options.text: Listicles are easier to process and understand than other forms of information.

options.label: C
options.text: Listicles are more creative and imaginative than other forms of information.

options.label: D
options.text: Listicles are more boring and uninteresting than other forms of information.

multiple-choice.question: According to Peter Dolittle, what is the size of our working memory?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of a basketball

options.label: B
options.text: The size of a pea

options.label: C
options.text: The size of a car

options.label: D
options.text: The size of a house

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of listicles as a format for education?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too long and take too much time to read.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too short and don't provide enough information.

options.label: C
options.text: They are limited in their capacity, duration, and focus, making it difficult to remember information.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too boring and uninteresting, making it difficult to stay engaged.

title: How many verb tenses are there in English? - Anna Ananichuk

multiple-choice.question: How many different tenses are there in a language like English?
What is the main difference between the simple and continuous aspects of a language?

options.label: A
options.text: The simple aspect describes actions that are finished, while the continuous aspect describes actions that are still happening.

options.label: B
options.text: The simple aspect describes actions that are still happening, while the continuous aspect describes actions that are finished.

options.label: C
options.text: The simple aspect describes actions that are still happening, while the continuous aspect describes actions that are ongoing.

options.label: D
options.text: The simple aspect describes actions that are finished, while the continuous aspect describes actions that are ongoing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the past perfect tense in a language?

options.label: A
options.text: To describe an action that occurred before another action in the past.

options.label: B
options.text: To describe an action that occurred after another action in the past.

options.label: C
options.text: To describe an action that occurred at the same time as another action in the past.

options.label: D
options.text: To describe an action that occurred in the present.

title: Why do mirrors flip horizontally (but not vertically)?

multiple-choice.question: Why do mirrors appear to flip things horizontally but not vertically?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the mirror is reflecting the image in a way that only flips it horizontally.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the mirror is not reflecting the image at all, but rather creating a new image.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the viewer is flipping the image horizontally when looking at it in the mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror is not capable of reflecting images in a vertical direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why we think things are horizontally flipped when they're really not?

options.label: A
options.text: Because most words we see in the mirror are on t-shirts and we don't think of them as horizontally flipped.

options.label: B
options.text: Because most of us are left and right symmetric and it's hard to see what's wrong with the image.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we flip the image away from our normal reading position when we look at it in the mirror.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we are not vertically symmetric and it's easy to see what's wrong with the image.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you flip an arrow in the z direction when looking at it in a mirror?

options.label: A
options.text: The arrow appears to be pointing in the opposite direction.

options.label: B
options.text: The arrow appears to be pointing in the same direction.

options.label: C
options.text: The arrow appears to be pointing forward.

options.label: D
options.text: The arrow appears to be pointing backward.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the z direction flip in the context of mirror reflections?

options.label: A
options.text: To flip the image horizontally.

options.label: B
options.text: To flip the image vertically.

options.label: C
options.text: To flip the image in the z direction, which is the direction from front to back.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a new image.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the mirror appear to flip the image in the z direction?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the mirror is reflecting the image in a way that only flips it in the z direction.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the viewer is flipping the image in the z direction when looking at it in the mirror.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the mirror is not capable of reflecting images in a z direction.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the image is being flipped in the z direction by the viewer's brain.

title: What are mini brains? - Madeline Lancaster

multiple-choice.question: What is a brain organoid, and what can it be used for?

options.label: A
options.text: A collection of lab-grown neurons and other brain tissue that scientists can use to study the human brain, but it can't think for itself.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of brain tissue that can be used to treat Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: C
options.text: A device that can simulate the human brain's functions.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of stem cell that can develop into any tissue in the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge that neuroscientists face when trying to understand the human brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain is too small to study.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain is too complex to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain is shielded by thick skulls and protective tissue, making it difficult to observe in action.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain is too simple to study.

multiple-choice.question: How are brain organoids grown?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a special gel to simulate embryonic tissue, a warm incubator set at body temperature, and a bit of motion to mimic blood flow.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a combination of sugars, proteins, vitamins, and minerals that induce the stem cell to develop a neural identity.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a special machine that can simulate the human brain's functions.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a type of stem cell that can develop into any tissue in the body.

multiple-choice.question: Why can't brain organoids think for themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they don't have the same tissue types as a full-sized brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they aren't organized the same way as a full-sized brain.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have only about 100,000 neurons compared to the 86 billion in a full-sized brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they can't interact with the outside world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: They can't be grown to a larger size.

options.label: B
options.text: They can't interact with the outside world.

options.label: C
options.text: They can't think for themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: They can't be used to study the human brain.

title: How to manage your time more effectively (according to machines) - Brian Christian

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem with NASA's Pathfinder spacecraft in the summer of 1997?

options.label: A
options.text: It was experiencing a software glitch that caused it to stop transmitting images.

options.label: B
options.text: It was running out of battery power and couldn't recharge.

options.label: C
options.text: It had a bug in its scheduler that caused it to procrastinate.

options.label: D
options.text: It was experiencing a hardware failure that caused it to shut down.

multiple-choice.question: What is a quadratic-time algorithm, and how does it affect productivity?

options.label: A
options.text: A quadratic-time algorithm is a fast way to prioritize tasks, but it can lead to procrastination.

options.label: B
options.text: A quadratic-time algorithm is a slow way to prioritize tasks, but it can lead to productivity.

options.label: C
options.text: A quadratic-time algorithm is a way to prioritize tasks that takes longer as the number of tasks increases, leading to decreased productivity.

options.label: D
options.text: A quadratic-time algorithm is a way to prioritize tasks that takes less time as the number of tasks increases, leading to increased productivity.

multiple-choice.question: What was the solution to the problem of Linux spending too much time ranking tasks in order of importance?

options.label: A
options.text: The programmers replaced the full ranking with a limited number of priority "buckets."

options.label: B
options.text: The programmers added more resources to the system to speed up task ranking.

options.label: C
options.text: The programmers changed the way tasks were assigned to the CPU to reduce ranking time.

options.label: D
options.text: The programmers removed the task ranking feature altogether.

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental tradeoff between productivity and responsiveness, and how can it be managed?

options.label: A
options.text: Productivity and responsiveness are mutually exclusive, and can be increased simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: Productivity and responsiveness are in tension, and can be managed by minimizing interruptions.

options.label: C
options.text: Productivity and responsiveness are in tension, and can be managed by grouping interruptions.

options.label: D
options.text: Productivity and responsiveness are in tension, and can be managed by increasing the number of context switches.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of interrupt coalescing, and how can it be applied to human productivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Interrupt coalescing reduces the number of context switches, leading to decreased productivity.

options.label: B
options.text: Interrupt coalescing increases the number of context switches, leading to increased productivity.

options.label: C
options.text: Interrupt coalescing groups interruptions together based on how long they can afford to wait, allowing for more efficient use of time.

options.label: D
options.text: Interrupt coalescing removes the need for task prioritization altogether.

title: Why do animals form swarms? - Maria R. D'Orsogna

multiple-choice.question: What triggers locusts to change their behavior from solitary to swarming when food becomes scarce?

options.label: A
options.text: Contact between different locusts' antennae

options.label: B
options.text: Contact between different locusts' hind legs

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of predators

options.label: D
options.text: Change in weather conditions

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of swarms, including locusts, that allows them to accomplish tasks they couldn't do individually?

options.label: A
options.text: Complex decision-making by individual members

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of a single leader

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to follow simple rules and interact with nearest neighbors

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to communicate with each other through complex language

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a problem that can arise when swarming organisms follow simple rules without a leader?

options.label: A
options.text: Disease spreading more easily

options.label: B
options.text: Increased efficiency in navigation

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to find a mate more easily

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to accomplish tasks they couldn't do individually

multiple-choice.question: What can humans learn from collective swarm-based organization in terms of technology?

options.label: A
options.text: How to design more efficient buildings

options.label: B
options.text: How to navigate confined spaces without colliding

options.label: C
options.text: How to develop more complex decision-making algorithms

options.label: D
options.text: How to design more powerful engines

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a beneficial aspect of swarming that can have catastrophic consequences?

options.label: A
options.text: More efficient navigation

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to find a mate more easily

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to accomplish tasks they couldn't do individually

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to follow simple rules and interact with nearest neighbors

title: Why is Herodotus called “The Father of History”? - Mark Robinson

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason for Herodotus's interest in the Persian Wars?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted to record the events as a list of facts.

options.label: B
options.text: He grew up during a series of wars between the Persians and the Greeks.

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to understand the reasons behind the events.

options.label: D
options.text: He was ordered by the Persian Empire to write about the wars.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Battle of Marathon, according to Herodotus?

options.label: A
options.text: The Persians won a decisive victory.

options.label: B
options.text: The Athenians won an unexpected victory.

options.label: C
options.text: The battle was a draw.

options.label: D
options.text: The battle did not occur.

options.label: A
options.text: Thermopylae

options.label: B
options.text: Marathon

options.label: C
options.text: Halicarnassus

options.label: D
options.text: Athens

options.label: A
options.text: Autopsy

options.label: B
options.text: Akoe

options.label: C
options.text: Ta legomena

options.label: D
options.text: Gnome

options.label: A
options.text: The Father of History

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Can 100% renewable energy power the world? - Federico Rosei and Renzo Rosei

multiple-choice.question: How much of the world's oil has been consumed so far?
What is one of the main challenges in using renewable energy to power homes and businesses?

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of sunlight in densely populated regions

options.label: B
options.text: The high cost of building a connected electrical energy network

options.label: C
options.text: The inefficiency of solar plants in capturing energy

options.label: D
options.text: The difficulty in transporting energy from where it's generated to where it's needed

options.label: A
options.text: They are too heavy

options.label: B
options.text: They have low energy density

options.label: C
options.text: They are too expensive

options.label: D
options.text: They are not efficient enough

options.label: A
options.text: Developing advanced technologies to capture energy more efficiently

options.label: B
options.text: Building a connected electrical energy network with power lines crisscrossing the globe

options.label: C
options.text: Finding efficient ways to convert solar into chemical energy

options.label: D
options.text: Using superconductors to transport electricity without dissipation

options.text: The lack of investment in renewable energy technologies

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How long will human impacts last? - David Biello

multiple-choice.question: What is the proposed start date for the Anthropocene, a new geologic epoch that reflects the impact of humans on the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: 10,000 years ago

options.label: B
options.text: 40,000 years ago

options.label: D
options.text: 1 million years ago

multiple-choice.question: What is an epoch in the geologic time scale?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of rock formation

options.label: B
options.text: A unit of geologic time

options.label: C
options.text: A type of climate change

options.label: D
options.text: A type of fossil

multiple-choice.question: What will the Anthropocene epoch be characterized by in the geologic record?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of new types of rocks

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of new types of fossils

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of novel elements like plutonium and plastics

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of new types of minerals

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: 4 billion metric tons

options.label: C
options.text: 8 billion metric tons

options.label: D
options.text: 12 billion metric tons

options.label: A
options.text: Increased biodiversity

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A homogenous world of certain favored plants and animals

options.label: D

title: History vs. Che Guevara - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary reason Che Guevara left his privileged life as a medical student in Argentina to travel through rural Latin America?

options.label: A
options.text: To study medicine in different parts of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: To witness the poverty and misery in the region and become a revolutionary.

options.label: C
options.text: To pursue a career in politics.

options.label: D
options.text: To escape the responsibilities of his family.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of President Árbenz's reforms in Guatemala?

options.label: A
options.text: The reforms led to a significant increase in the standard of land owned by the government.

options.label: B
options.text: The reforms were met with resistance from the military, and Árbenz was overthrown in a CIA-sponsored coup.

options.label: C
options.text: The reforms led to a decrease in the poverty rate among the population.

options.label: D
options.text: The reforms had no significant impact on the country's economy.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason Che Guevara was instrumental in helping Fidel Castro seize power in Cuba?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a skilled military strategist who helped the rebels defeat the government forces.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a charismatic leader who inspired the people to support the revolution.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a commander in Castro's guerilla army who unleashed a reign of terror across the countryside.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a key advisor to Castro who helped him make strategic decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Che Guevara's leadership in Cuba?

options.label: A
options.text: He oversaw a significant increase in the country's GDP and improved living standards for the population.

options.label: B
options.text: He established a democratic government and protected the rights of the people.

options.label: C
options.text: He implemented land redistribution, established universal education, and organized volunteer literacy brigades, but also suppressed press freedom and declared that newspapers were instruments of the oligarchy.

options.label: D
options.text: He failed to implement any significant reforms and was eventually overthrown.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Che Guevara's attempt to spread the revolution abroad?

options.label: A
options.text: He successfully rallied rebels in several countries and established a new government in each of them.

options.label: B
options.text: He failed to rally rebels in several countries, but his efforts inspired a new generation of activists.

options.label: C
options.text: He was captured and executed by government forces in Bolivia, but his legacy lived on.

options.label: D
options.text: He was forced to return to Cuba and was eventually put on trial for his crimes.

title: What is the tragedy of the commons? - Nicholas Amendolare

multiple-choice.question: In the example of the fish pond, what is the optimal number of fish that each fisherman should catch each day to maximize their food supply?
What is the phenomenon described by economist William Forster Lloyd in 1833 in a discussion of the overgrazing of cattle on village common areas?

options.label: A
options.text: The Tragedy of the Commons

options.label: B
options.text: The Overgrazing Problem

options.label: C
options.text: The Commons Dilemma

options.label: D
options.text: The Resource Management Crisis

multiple-choice.question: According to Garrett Hardin, what is the key feature of a tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides an opportunity for individuals to benefit themselves while spreading out any negative effects across the larger population.

options.label: B
options.text: It results in long-term gains for individuals while causing short-term losses.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to overuse of resources due to a lack of regulations.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a result of a lack of social contracts.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of the tragedy of the commons in real life, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The overuse of antibiotics has led to short-term gains in livestock production but resulted in the evolution of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

options.label: B
options.text: The overuse of coal-fired power plants has led to pollution and climate change.

options.label: C
options.text: The overuse of water has led to water shortages.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the key to solving the problems caused by the tragedy of the commons?

options.label: A
options.text: Forming social contracts and making communal agreements.

options.label: B
options.text: Electing governments and passing laws.

options.label: C
options.text: Relying on individual impulses.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the problem and hoping it goes away.

title: How often should you get a flu shot? - Melvin Sanicas

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: A
options.text: The flu virus has a high mortality rate.

options.label: B
options.text: The flu virus mutates quickly, changing its genetic code.

options.label: C
options.text: The flu virus is not contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: The flu virus is only spread through direct contact.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the flu virus and other viruses that can cause diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: The flu virus has a longer incubation period.

options.label: B
options.text: The flu virus has a lower transmission rate.

options.label: C
options.text: The flu virus has a faster mutation rate due to its RNA genetic material.

options.label: D
options.text: The flu virus is only spread through airborne transmission.

multiple-choice.question: How does the flu vaccine work?

options.label: A
options.text: The flu vaccine contains live viruses that infect the body and trigger an immune response.

options.label: B
options.text: The flu vaccine contains antigens that are recognized by the immune system as foreign and trigger an immune response.

options.label: C
options.text: The flu vaccine contains antibodies that directly fight the flu virus.

options.label: D
options.text: The flu vaccine contains a weakened form of the flu virus that is not capable of making the person sick.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in developing a universal flu vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: The flu virus has a high mortality rate.

options.label: B
options.text: The flu virus mutates quickly, changing its genetic code.

options.label: C
options.text: The flu virus is not contagious.

options.label: D
options.text: The flu virus has a complex genetic structure that makes it difficult to develop a vaccine that can protect against all strains.

multiple-choice.question: What is herd immunity, and how does the flu vaccine contribute to it?

options.label: A
options.text: Herd immunity is a state where a community is protected from a disease because a large percentage of its members have been vaccinated.

options.label: B
options.text: Herd immunity is a state where a community is protected from a disease because a large percentage of its members have contracted the disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Herd immunity is a state where a community is protected from a disease because a large percentage of its members have died from the disease.

options.label: D
options.text: Herd immunity is a state where a community is protected from a disease because a large percentage of its members have been infected with a different disease.

title: Why incompetent people think they're amazing - David Dunning

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon where people overestimate their own abilities called?

options.label: A
options.text: The Dunning-Kruger effect

options.label: B
options.text: The self-esteem boost

options.label: C
options.text: Illusory superiority

options.label: D
options.text: The laws of math

multiple-choice.question: According to researchers, which group of people are most likely to overrate their skills to the greatest extent?

options.label: A
options.text: People with average ability

options.label: B
options.text: People with the least ability

options.label: C
options.text: People with the most experience

options.label: D
options.text: People with the most knowledge

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why people with the least ability are often unable to recognize their own mistakes?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too confident

options.label: B
options.text: They lack the knowledge and skill to recognize their errors

options.label: C
options.text: They are too humble

options.label: D
options.text: They are too busy

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to find out how good you actually are at various things?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask for feedback from other people and consider it

options.label: B
options.text: Only rely on your own judgment

options.label: C
options.text: Keep learning and becoming more knowledgeable

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and C

multiple-choice.question: What is a common mistake that experts make in terms of their self-perception?

options.label: A
options.text: They assume they are less knowledgeable than others

options.label: B
options.text: They assume everyone else is knowledgeable, too

options.label: C
options.text: They overestimate their abilities

options.label: D

title: Can you solve the egg drop riddle? - Yossi Elran

multiple-choice.question: A thief is trying to steal a priceless egg from a 100-story building by dropping it out the window. The eggs are identical in weight and construction, but each floor's egg is more rare and valuable than the one below it. What is the least number of tries it would take to guarantee that she finds the right floor?

options.label: A
options.text: 19 tries

options.label: B
options.text: 14 tries

options.label: C
options.text: 100 tries

options.label: D
options.text: 50 tries

multiple-choice.question: The thief has two souvenir eggs, perfect replicas that are perfectly worthless. What is the purpose of using these replica eggs?

options.label: A
options.text: To test the security of the building

options.label: B
options.text: To find the highest floor at which an egg will survive the fall without breaking

options.label: C
options.text: To distract the guards

options.label: D
options.text: To steal the priceless egg

multiple-choice.question: If the thief starts by dropping the first egg from every 10th floor, how many tries will it take to find the right floor?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 tries

options.label: B
options.text: 19 tries

options.label: C
options.text: 20 tries

options.label: D
options.text: 25 tries

multiple-choice.question: What is the optimal way to divide the building into sections to find the right floor with the least number of tries?

options.label: A
options.text: Divide the building into sections of equal size

options.label: B
options.text: Divide the building into sections where each interval is one floor smaller than the last

options.label: C
options.text: Divide the building into sections of random size

options.label: D
options.text: Divide the building into sections based on the value of the eggs

multiple-choice.question: What is the first floor that the thief should start with in the 100-floor building to guarantee that she finds the right floor with the least number of tries?

options.label: A
options.text: 1st floor

options.label: B
options.text: 10th floor

options.label: C
options.text: 14th floor

options.label: D
options.text: 20th floor
